misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for a different problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three double values, which matches an average-acceleration physics problem rather than the requirement to read five integers to sum the even ones.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to compute average acceleration from starting velocity, final velocity, and time, and that reading those three doubles is the correct input behavior.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt in a loop or sequence), because the assignment is to compute the sum of the even numbers among those five integers.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers
Program calls nextDouble three times, never nextInt
There is no way to provide five integer inputs to this program
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a different average-acceleration exercise or misread the current assignment, implementing the physics problem instead of the required sum-of-even-numbers problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the physics-specific prompt and nextDouble calls with code that reads five integers from the user, preferably using nextInt and either a loop or a sequence of five input statements.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard with Scanner
Choosing appropriate input methods for integer vs. double
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Variable names, prompt text, and use of nextDouble all clearly correspond to a standard average-acceleration example and not to a sum-of-even-numbers task.

evidence.note: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three doubles, not five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: Does not use a loop to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program reads a small fixed set of values into separate variables and never uses a loop, so it cannot systematically handle five similar inputs as expected in this task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes it is sufficient to read each required value into its own variable without using a loop, even when the problem involves a fixed number of similar inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem requires processing several similar inputs (like five integers), a loop should be used to repeat the same input-and-processing steps for each value, which also simplifies accumulation logic.
symptoms: No for or while loop appears in the program
Input statements (nextDouble) appear three times and are not inside any loop
There is no index variable or repeated processing pattern for multiple inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may not yet be comfortable applying loops to handle repeated input and instead falls back on separate variables for each value.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that runs 5 times, each time reading one integer and (after checking if it is even) updating a running sum. This eliminates the need for separate variables like startingVelocity and finalVelocity.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of any loop, combined with fixed variable names, indicates the student is not using a loop structure for processing repeated inputs.

evidence.note: Entire main method has no for/while loop; inputs are read into fixed variables instead of being processed in a loop.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether any number is even (using % 2 == 0 or similar), so it cannot implement the core requirement of summing only even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is focused on computing average acceleration and does not appear to consider any need to filter inputs by whether they are even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only the even numbers, each input should be tested with a conditional like if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the running sum.
symptoms: No use of the % operator in the program
No if statement that tests whether a value is even
All arithmetic combines velocity and time values to compute acceleration, not to filter integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented the wrong problem, they did not implement any logic related to even numbers or conditionals on input values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, add an if statement: if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }. This ensures only even numbers contribute to the total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional or modulo operation anywhere in the code that could fulfill the 'even numbers' requirement.

evidence.note: All arithmetic is about velocities and time; there is no if statement or % 2 == 0 check for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Computes average acceleration instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program calculates changeInVelocity and averageAcceleration and prints a physics-related message instead of maintaining a sum of even integers and printing 'Sum of even numbers: <sum>'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the goal is to calculate and print 'The average acceleration' from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer sum variable initialized to 0, add each even input to this sum, and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
symptoms: Variables are named startingVelocity, finalVelocity, time, changeInVelocity, averageAcceleration
The printed message is 'The average acceleration is ...'
There is no integer sum variable and no accumulation of input values
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely copied or adapted a solution to an 'average acceleration' problem and did not translate it to the current assignment about summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the physics-specific calculations and introduce an int sum = 0. For each even input, do sum += n; and at the end print 'Sum of even numbers: ' + sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every computation and the final output string are about acceleration, with no sign of a sum-of-evens calculation.

evidence.note: Instead of summing integers, the code computes and prints an average acceleration value.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Deviation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different programming problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the requested task (summing even numbers among five inputs). Consequently, the code lacks the necessary control structures (loop, conditional check) and data input handling (5 integers) required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the code submitted fulfills the requirement to calculate the sum of even numbers from five inputs, or they submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program must read five integer inputs and use a loop combined with an accumulator and a modulo operator check to filter and sum only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration (v1 - v0) / t
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integers
Missing loop and conditional logic (if (n % 2 == 0))
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or complete deviation from the assignment requirements, likely due to submitting the wrong assignment file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and ensure the submitted program addresses the requirements: reading 5 integers, using a loop, checking for even numbers, and accumulating the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a globally recognized formula (acceleration) and explicitly prompts for related variables (v0, v1, t), which is entirely incompatible with the given problem statement (Sum of Even Numbers).

evidence.note: The class name itself indicates the code's purpose is unrelated to the assignment.
The program reads 3 double variables and performs acceleration calculation, instead of reading 5 integers and calculating a sum.

misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration calculator instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description:
STEP 1: Expected behavior
- Read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., using a loop with Scanner.nextInt()).
- Use a loop to process the 5 inputs.
- For each number, check if it is even with n % 2 == 0.
- Maintain an accumulator variable (e.g., int sum = 0) and add only even numbers to this sum.
- After processing all 5 numbers, print: "Sum of even numbers: " followed by the sum.

STEP 2: What the student's code does
- Asks the user to "Enter v0, v1, and t:".
- Reads three double values (startingVelocity, finalVelocity, time) using nextDouble().
- Computes changeInVelocity = finalVelocity - startingVelocity.
- Computes averageAcceleration = changeInVelocity / time.
- Prints "The average acceleration is " followed by the computed acceleration.
- There is no loop, no modulus (%), no test for even numbers, and no accumulation of a sum of selected inputs.

STEP 3: Divergences
1) Problem being solved
- Code: The entire program is about v0, v1, t, and average acceleration.
- Does: Solves a physics formula problem (average acceleration from initial and final velocity and time).
- Should do: Solve a numeric processing problem: read 5 integers, select even ones, and sum them.

2) Inputs and data types
- Code: Reads 3 doubles using nextDouble().
- Does: Accepts 3 floating-point values representing physical quantities.
- Should do: Read 5 integers using nextInt() so parity (even/odd) is well-defined and all 5 values are considered.

3) Loop structure
- Code: No loop; only a straight-line sequence of 3 input operations and calculations.
- Does: Processes exactly 3 inputs once.
- Should do: Use a loop (for or while) that iterates 5 times to handle 5 inputs systematically.

4) Conditional even check
- Code: No conditional involving % or checking for evenness.
- Does: Never distinguishes even from odd; just uses the values in a formula.
- Should do: Use if (n % 2 == 0) to decide whether to add each number to the sum.

5) Accumulating and printing sum
- Code: Computes averageAcceleration and prints it with a physics-oriented message.
- Does: Outputs the acceleration value.
- Should do: Maintain an integer sum initialized to 0, add only even numbers, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " plus the sum.

STEP 4: Diagnosis (WHY)
- Nature of error: Conceptual/procedural at the problem level, not a small typo. The student appears to have implemented a completely different exercise (average acceleration) instead of the required one (sum of even integers).
- Likely student belief: "The assignment is to compute the average acceleration from v0, v1, and t using (v1 - v0) / t." They may have copied or reused code from a textbook example or previous question.
- Correct understanding: The task is a small data-processing program: read 5 integers, use a loop to get them all, test each for evenness using n % 2 == 0, accumulate only the even numbers in a sum, and print that sum.
- Topic category: Other (global mismatch between problem requirements and implemented solution rather than a narrow issue with variables, data types, or input syntax).

STEP 5: Score against rubric
- Reading 5 integers from input (1.0 pt): 0/1
  * Program reads 3 doubles, not 5 integers, and uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt().
- Loop structure to process inputs (1.0 pt): 0/1
  * No loop is used; inputs are read once each in straight-line code.
- Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0) (1.0 pt): 0/1
  * There is no modulus operator, no condition on evenness at all.
- Accumulating sum and printing result (1.0 pt): 0/1
  * No accumulator for even numbers, and the printed result is an average acceleration, not a sum of even integers.

STEP 6: Summary
- Total score: 0/4
- Key issue: The program solves the wrong problem (average acceleration) and therefore misses all required elements: reading 5 integers, looping, checking evenness, and summing.
- Overall feedback: Re-read the problem statement carefully before coding. Start by writing pseudocode: (1) initialize sum = 0; (2) repeat 5 times: read an int n; if n % 2 == 0 then sum += n; (3) print the sum with the required message. Then translate that step-by-step into Java with a for loop, nextInt() for input, an if condition using %, and an integer accumulator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is to compute the average acceleration from initial velocity v0, final velocity v1, and time t using the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment is to read 5 integers from the keyboard, use a loop to process all 5, check each with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt message asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program reads exactly three double values using nextDouble() instead of five integers
No loop is present to process multiple inputs
No use of the modulus operator % or any even/odd test
Output message reports average acceleration rather than sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading of the problem statement or reuse of a textbook/example solution for an average acceleration problem instead of implementing the requested sum-of-evens algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the task in your own words and sketch pseudocode. For this problem: use a for loop that runs 5 times, read an int each time with nextInt(), if (n % 2 == 0) then add it to an int sum, and after the loop print "Sum of even numbers: " + sum. Only then translate that plan into Java.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition and reading specifications carefully
Loops for processing a fixed number of inputs
Using the modulus operator (%) to test for even numbers
Using accumulators to build up a sum
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every key element of the code (variable names, prompt string, formula) matches a standard average-acceleration example and none of the required behaviors for summing even integers are present.

evidence.note: Program is set up as an acceleration calculator and reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers as required.
Core logic computes and prints average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers; no loop, no % operator, no accumulator.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard for problem statement requirements (Program Logic)
misconceptions.description: The submitted code attempts to solve an entirely different problem (calculating acceleration from velocity and time) instead of responding to the requirements of the assigned task (reading 5 integers and summing the evens). This indicates a fundamental failure to adhere to assignment specifications.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have submitted code for a previous or unrelated assignment (e.g., 'AccelerationCalculator') believing it satisfies the current requirements, or perhaps misunderstanding the entire scope of the current task (Q1).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program must initialize a sum variable, perform a loop 5 times, read an integer within the loop, check if the integer is even using the modulo operator, and accumulate the sum if it is even, finally printing the accumulated result.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration instead of an even sum
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Missing loop and conditional logic required for the task
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error, catastrophic misinterpretation of the task, or copying/submitting code from an entirely different context.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Step back and carefully reread the problem statement ('Sum of Even Numbers'). Write the code line-by-line using proper variables, loops, input methods (nextInt), and conditional checks (if/modulo).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names, inputs, and output are completely inconsistent with the required task, demonstrating this program is for a different purpose.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the code is calculating acceleration, not summing even numbers.
The prompt asks for velocities and time, not 5 general integers.
The core calculation and output relate to acceleration, not summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Wrong data type for integer input
misconceptions.description: Student used nextDouble() to read input as doubles instead of using nextInt() to read integers. Also reads only 3 values instead of 5.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the input should be read as decimal numbers (doubles) rather than whole integers, or misread the problem requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem specifically asks for 5 integers. Use Scanner.nextInt() to read integer values, not nextDouble(). The variable type should match the data being read (int, not double).
symptoms: Code reads 3 values instead of 5
Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
Uses double data type for input variables
No loop to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied code from a different assignment (physics acceleration problem) rather than writing code for this specific problem, or confused integer vs. floating-point input methods.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for-loop from 0 to 4 to read exactly 5 integers. Replace nextDouble() with nextInt(). Change variable declarations from 'double' to 'int'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads the wrong number of inputs (3 instead of 5) and uses the wrong data type (double vs. int). This is unambiguous evidence.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 doubles with separate nextDouble() calls instead of reading 5 integers in a loop with nextInt().

evidence.snippet:
double startingVelocity
double finalVelocity
double time
evidence.note: Variables declared as 'double' instead of 'int', indicating the student is working with wrong data type for this problem.

misconceptions.name: Missing loop for multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: Student hardcoded three separate input statements instead of using a loop structure to read multiple inputs. This approach is inefficient and doesn't scale to the required 5 integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that separate input statements for each variable are acceptable, or did not understand the need for a loop to process 5 inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A loop structure (for or while) should be used to read multiple inputs efficiently. For reading 5 integers, a for-loop from 0 to 4 would be the standard approach.
symptoms: Only 3 hardcoded input statements
Cannot accommodate 5 inputs as required
Inefficient code design for multiple inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied template code that did not use loops, or did not recognize the need for iteration to handle multiple values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three hardcoded input statements with a for-loop: for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any loop construct is unambiguous. The code explicitly contains only 3 hardcoded input calls.

evidence.note: Three hardcoded input statements with no loop structure. Required to read 5 integers but only reads 3.

misconceptions.name: Missing even/odd filtering logic
misconceptions.description: Student's code contains no conditional logic to check whether a number is even. The modulo operator (%) and if statement required to filter even numbers are completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either did not read the full problem requirements or is unaware that filtering even numbers requires explicit conditional logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To identify even numbers, use the condition (n % 2 == 0) within an if statement. The modulo operator (%) returns the remainder after division; if n % 2 equals 0, the number is even.
symptoms: No if statement in code
No modulo operator (%) usage
All input values are processed the same way (no filtering)
No condition to distinguish even from odd
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) which naturally does not involve even/odd logic. Likely a submission error.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the input loop, add: if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; } to accumulate only even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code performs physics calculations (acceleration = (v1-v0)/t) with no trace of even/odd logic anywhere.

evidence.note: Code performs velocity/time calculation with no conditional checks for even/odd filtering. Completely solves wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Missing sum accumulator variable
misconceptions.description: Student does not use a sum accumulator variable to collect even numbers. Instead, the code performs an unrelated calculation (acceleration) and outputs a completely different result.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student does not appear to recognize the need for an accumulator pattern (a variable that maintains a running total).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To solve this problem, declare an int variable to store the sum (e.g., 'int sum = 0;'). After checking if each number is even, add it to this variable and output the final sum.
symptoms: No 'sum' or accumulator variable declared
Output shows acceleration calculation, not sum of even numbers
Variables used (startingVelocity, finalVelocity, time) are unrelated to the problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong assignment (acceleration calculator instead of sum of even numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add 'int sum = 0;' before the loop. Inside the loop, after checking 'if (num % 2 == 0)', add 'sum += num;'. Finally, print 'sum' with the appropriate message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains zero accumulator logic and outputs completely different content (acceleration instead of sum).

evidence.note: Output is acceleration, not sum of even numbers. No accumulator variable used at any point.
